ympes 1.4.0.9000

  • Changelog

Argument assertions

Source: R/assert.R
assertions.Rd

Assertions for function arguments. Motivated by vctrs::vec_assert() but with lower overhead at a cost of less informative error messages. Designed to make it easy to identify the top level calling function whether used within a user facing function or internally.

Usage

assert_integer(
  x,
  ...,
  .arg = deparse(substitute(x)),
  .call = sys.call(-1L),
  .subclass = NULL
)

assert_int(
  x,
  ...,
  .arg = deparse(substitute(x)),
  .call = sys.call(-1L),
  .subclass = NULL
)

  x,
  ...,
  .arg = deparse(substitute(x)),
  .call = sys.call(-1L),
  .subclass = NULL
)

Arguments

x

Argument to check.

...

Additional fields that will be added to the resulting error condition

.arg

[character]

Name of argument being checked (used in error message).

.call

[call]

Call to use in error message.

.subclass

[character]

The (optional) subclass of the returned error condition.

Value

NULL if the assertion succeeds (error otherwise).

Examples


# Use in a user facing function
fun <- function(i, d, l, chr, b) {
    assert_scalar_int(i)
    TRUE
}
fun(i=1L)
#> [1] TRUE
try(fun())
#> Error in fun() : argument `i` is missing, with no default.
try(fun(i="cat"))
#> Error in fun() : `i` must be an integer vector of length 1.

# Use in an internal function
internal_fun <- function(a) {
    assert_string(
        a,
        .arg = deparse(substitute(x)),
        .call = sys.call(-1L),
        .subclass = "example_error"
    )
    TRUE
}
external_fun <- function(b) {
    internal_fun(a=b)
}
external_fun(b="cat")
#> [1] TRUE
try(external_fun())
#> Error in external_fun() : argument `x` is missing, with no default.
try(external_fun(b = letters))
#> Error in external_fun() : `x` must be a character vector of length 1.
tryCatch(external_fun(b = letters), error = class)
#> [1] "example_error" "error"         "condition"
